ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We would sometimes have smaller group sessions with the professor.
Other modes were the weekly individual/ partner sessions as well as weekly Tutorials with TFs.
We only used the virtual seminar format.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I became more fluent and more comfortable with spoken Chinese. I also learned a lot of new vocabulary
Chinese grammar, speaking, and listening skills. Relatively limited writing skills.
a lot of chinese speaking

I improved my conversational (listening and speaking) abilities in this course. Along with learning new vocabulary and sentence structures, I practiced and improved my writing abilities, especially in longer formats.
I improved my knowledge of Chinese.
I developed a stronger understanding of Chinese vocabulary and grammar structures. I also believe my reading comprehension and listening has improved significantly.
My writing skills in Mandarin significantly improved as a result of the the essays we had to write throughout the semester! I also learned of better ways to study for written and oral assessments.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It is challenging, but very rewarding - can't think of anything to improve. It was adapted well to the virtual environment
Strengths: instructor, consistent but manageable workload. Weaknesses: would be nice to engage with more resources apart from the textbook e.g. news articles covering current events.
the strengths are definitely improved speaking, but i didn't really master writing characters

This course is very good at making you engage with the language, yet, there were some assignments that felt unnecessarily long. For example, we would have to rewrite our essays by hand after being given corrections, each time with increasing minimum character count. These were helpful assignments, but could have been kept to the same length for equal effect.

This is definitely a rigorous course and I found myself spending a lot of time every day reviewing the new vocabulary and grammar, but I saw tremendous improvement across my reading, writing, speaking, and listening. Also, the teachers are super helpful and passionate about what they are teaching.

I appreciate the type of the assignments given (the content), but at times it felt quite overwhelming when we had back-to-back essays, presentations, and assessments. It would be nice if they could be spread out because it felt as if at times I wasn't really learning anything, but moreso just cramming knowledge in my head for a test.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked the fact that the tests were open-book and that the quizzes took place outside of class, and the fact that there was a very clear structure. I found that the course was just as effective as it was in-person

Maybe more could be done to facilitate back-and-forth conversations among students, although this is hard with Zoom. I think two breakout rooms of ~4 students each might be best for this. If the breakout rooms are too small its easy for it to become a little awkward and quiet.

Having class time set aside to meet with the teacher in smaller groups was helpful. It allowed the class to feel more connected to the instructor. Having some parts of the class, such as quizzes, be asynchronous was also very helpful for time management during an online semester.

I think the virtual format of the class was effective-- all students were able to participate and we were also able to work in smaller groups with the break-out room function on Zoom to practice dialogues and sentence patterns.
I liked the online games we played together because they were very engaging! Nothing to critique.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, but if you are taking this course you're probably already familiar with how much work this course requires. I didn't find it worse than L1 and L2, and it is definitely very rewarding, so definitely take it if you want to quickly improve your Chinese (but make sure you have the time to do the work!)
Yes - it isn't really possible to pass this course and not get anything out of it.
yes.

I would recommend this course to another student. I could notice that my Chinese was improving and that I felt more confident talking to friends of mine that were native speakers. It is hard work, but it is worth it.
If you want to get better at Chinese, yes.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who genuinely wants to learn Chinese. It is a commitment because there are daily assignments and a lot of self-studying but manageable and well-organized at the same time. Since the class meets every day, I found my Chinese improved significantly and so it was very rewarding.

If you've been studying Mandarin for a while, I think this is an excellent course to introduce you to the Chinese department at Yale! Prior to starting L3 at Yale, I've studied Mandarin since my freshman year of high school, and I feel as if this course suited my current Chinese capabilities and pushed me farther in my studies.
